race.name: Dirty 30
race.tagline: Early season Michigan gravel with cold starts, mud risk, and MGRS community.

climate.description: Cold starts (35-60°F), mud risk, variable spring weather.

terrain.surface: Forest roads, rural gravel. 3,500 ft over 100 miles = constant rollers. No big climbs, just relentless ups and downs. Spring conditions = potential mud.

biased_opinion.summary: Dirty 30 is a Michigan Gravel Race Series event in April—meaning cold starts, mud potential, and early season fitness reality checks. 100 miles, 3,500 ft of constant rollers (no big climbs, just relentless ups and downs). Field is ~500, vibe is regional community. This isn't a destination race; it's a solid early season test for Midwest riders. If you're from Michigan or nearby, it's a good value ($45-$75). If you're flying in, there are better options.
strengths: Excellent value ($45-$75 for multiple distance options)
Early season race for Midwest riders
weaknesses: No big climbs, just constant rollers (some find monotonous)
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you're in Michigan or the Midwest and want an early season race, Dirty 30 is solid. It's affordable, community-focused, and a good fitness test. If you're traveling from afar, this isn't worth the trip. Save your dollars and vacation days for something bigger.

logistics.nearest_airport: Gerald R. Ford International (GRR, Grand Rapids) — 40 miles west
logistics.lodging_note: Saranac is small. Lodging limited. Grand Rapids (40 miles) has more options.
logistics.travel_summary: Grand Rapids airport closest. Rental car needed. Saranac is small—lodging limited. Stay in Grand Rapids if needed.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race food at finish.
logistics.camping: Check official website for camping options

course_description.character: Rolling Michigan gravel. Forest roads, rural gravel. 3,500 ft over 100 miles = constant rollers. No big climbs, just relentless ups and downs.

suffering_zones.name: Constant Rollers
suffering_zones.description: 3,500 ft spread over 100 miles. No big climbs, just constant ups and downs. Legs never rest.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Steady pacing. Don't burn matches on small climbs. Conserve for cumulative fatigue.

suffering_zones.name: April Cold Start
suffering_zones.description: Cold morning temps (35-45°F). Dress for cold, manage layers.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Layers. Arm/leg warmers, vest. Shed as it warms.

course_description.signature_challenge: Constant rolling terrain—cumulative elevation without big climbs. April cold and mud risk.

history.origin_story: Dirty 30 is part of Michigan Gravel Race Series. Early season event in Saranac. 500 riders, multiple distance options.
history.reputation: Regional early season race. MGRS community favorite.

logistics.explanation: Packet pickup Friday 5-7PM and Saturday 6-9:45AM at 17 South Bridge Street with clear parking at Saranac Community Schools. Multiple start times keep distances organized - Century at 7AM, Dirty 30 at 10:10AM. Kari Stuart solved parking constraints by getting dropped off: "Parking is very limited in Saranac, and I was determined not to have a car on there. So Ben dropped me off in Lowell the morning of the race and I road down the crushed gravel Fred Meyer trail into Saranac."

length.explanation: 100 miles rewards tactical riding over raw power in Michigan's rolling terrain. Stuart's wind-blocking strategy worked perfectly: "There he was – a broader man with calves like boulders and a very steady cadence. He was riding a bit quicker than I could maintain on my own, and boy did he do a good job of blocking the wind! So I hung on his back wheel for those stretches directly into the wind." Seven distance options from kids ride to Savage Century accommodate every rider level. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: Stuart describes 'hero gravel' surfaces built for speed, not bike handling skills. The course starts with "150 feet of gain over the first mile... nothing steep" then goes "relatively flat" for 12 miles. Even Ivan the Terrible near mile 30 is "steady and steep" but doesn't require technical navigation. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 3,500 feet over 100 miles creates strategic suffering through timing rather than sustained climbing. Ivan the Terrible delivers the signature punch positioned brutally "just a mile or two from the end of the race, which makes you wonder if gravel racing is maybe not all that fun after all." Stuart notes the payoff: "Once you get to the top, you get to soon soar down to the finish line." Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 57°F and lows of 38°F, with a 55% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 27 mph. Mid-April delivers testing conditions with dramatic temperature swings and serious wind exposure. Stuart experienced the full range: "Was 42° and sunny when Ben dropped me off... Out on the course... it was starting to get hot!" Combined with "no joke" 15-20 mph west-southwest winds, the weather rewards preparation and tactical clothing choices over thermal bibs and heavy jackets that others wore. Milder conditions than Crusher in the Tushar.

altitude.explanation: Starting around 150 feet elevation near Saranac keeps the race at sea level performance without acclimatization concerns. Stuart's course description confirms the low starting point: "All of The Dirty 30 routes start off with 150 feet of gain over the first mile." Lower Michigan terrain means elevation gain comes purely from rolling topography rather than atmospheric challenges. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Stuart highlights the "howl worthy downhill around mile 12" as the biggest thrill moment, plus a "fast and fun" finish descent. But she frames it clearly as "exactly what you want from a local gravel event" with smooth roads through Michigan countryside rather than epic wilderness tales.

prestige.explanation: Stuart calls it her "favorite event" but frames it clearly as a "local spring gravel opener" with a "small field." Part of the Michigan Gravel Race Series, it serves regional riders rather than destination racing. Stuart's tight finish shows competitive racing within the Michigan scene: "She took 1st in our age group, and I was 2nd with a difference of 6-seconds."

race_quality.explanation: Stuart calls it "exactly what you want from a local gravel event" with smooth organization and "perfect gravel roads." Seven distance options with staggered starts, clear packet pickup logistics show they've mastered small-town race management. The course delivers payoff moments riders want with the "fast and fun" finish following challenging climbs.

experience.explanation: Community reception varies dramatically depending on race day luck. Stuart brought her daughter Cassie for the free kids race, experiencing "nice vibe from the quaint little community of Saranac." But FlaggerVandy encountered hostility: "I am still taken aback by how unwelcoming the town of Saranac was to our event. Between the protester(?) with his burn pile, angry residents at the main intersection in town all day."

community.explanation: Small field creates personal racing where 6-second margins matter and families participate together. Stuart's daughter Cassie joined the free kids event, discovering gravel racing: "when I called her a 'rockstar' she replied, 'Well yea, we are riding on rocks, mom!'" The Michigan Gravel Race Series attracts committed regional riders who show up to compete seriously within their community.

field_depth.explanation: Stuart describes a "small field" where drafting strategy behind riders with "calves like boulders" matters more than raw power. Her 6-second loss in her age group shows competitive racing exists, but the field size allows for tactical moves that wouldn't work in deeper events. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Seven distance options maximize entry value from kids ride to Savage Century, with Cassie's free 3-mile event adding family appeal. Stuart's Fred Meyer trail approach from Lowell provided bonus training miles and parking solutions. Multiple race formats in one weekend, family programming, and Stuart's assessment as "exactly what you want from a local gravel event" deliver exceptional value per registration dollar.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $45-$75. Stuart's drop-off strategy and "close to home" description suggests accessibility for regional Michigan riders without major travel costs. Gerald R. Ford International Airport provides reasonable access for out-of-state riders. Stuart's clothing choice - avoiding the "thermal bibs, heavy jackets, mittens, and toe covers" others wore - shows budget-friendly gear works fine for prepared riders. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

final_verdict.one_liner: The Dirty 30 gets by on Michigan charm and distance options, but without signature terrain or serious prestige, it's more local weekend fun than destination race.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in the Midwest looking for solid training miles with low pressure, this works. The 100-mile option gives you century bragging rights without the Unbound brutality, and starting from downtown Saranac beats another cornfield parking lot. Skip it if you need technical challenges or want to test yourself against serious competition—3500 feet over 100 miles won't break anyone who's been riding longer than six months.
final_verdict.alternatives: Almanzo 100 in Minnesota delivers similar distance with more historic credibility and harder conditions. For Michigan riders wanting something with actual teeth, Lumberjack 100 up north will remind you why they make suspension seatposts.

primary.name: Schwalbe G-One Ultrabite
primary.why: excellent wet grip. strong mud clearance

primary.name: Tufo Gravel Swampero
primary.why: excellent wet grip. strong mud clearance

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Wet
primary.why: excellent wet grip. strong mud clearance

videos.title: Dirty 30 Gravel Race 2023
videos.description:
STS vists the Dirty 30 Gravel Race in Saranac, MI.  What a great day with 4 of our 5 riders ending up on the podium.  Personal bests happened all around, and it was such a great day.  See what our racers had to say about this awesome experience.

#exploration #exploration #madeinusa #cyclinglife #gravelbike #steelisreal #custompaint #cycling

videos.curation_reason: Team race recap with rider interviews providing insights into race conditions and atmosphere.

videos.title: 2022 Dirty 30 Filthy 50 Gravel Race (Saranac, MI)
videos.description: Gopro battery last only 20 minutes so that's why more video at the beginning Then I try to squeeze more footage towards the end but I wish I can have more. About racing, I still a lot to learn and need to train more power. Got drop only about 1/2 mile from the start. Also pick the worst line on the last turn before sprint finish.

videos.title: 2024 Dirty 30 Gravel Race 30mile Lead Group
videos.description: Dirty 30 Gravel Race in Saranac, Michigan. The 2nd stop of the Michigan Gravel Race Series. A beautiful 60 degree and sunny April race day. Big thanks to the promoters, volunteers, and the great people of Saranac, Michigan.
videos.curation_reason: Recent lead group footage showing competitive race dynamics with good view count and production quality.

videos.title: the Dirty 30 - 30 Mile Gravel race in Saranac, MI
videos.description:
Some clips of the Dirty 30, 4-13-24. my GoPro battery died about halfway through, unfortunately. I thought I had that figured out. 
Finish time was 2:04

Cool and very windy out there. gusts were easily 25mph or more at times. 
Tough day, but I enjoyed it thoroughly!

videos.title: 2023 Dirty 30 Gravel Race (Michigan Gravel Race Series)
videos.description: Mostly unedited footage from April 8th, 2023 gravel race out of Saranac. I ended up 10th overall and 1st in age group. Ended up cramping going up Ivan Rd and lost the leaders. There's a hard crash at 49:45.
videos.curation_reason: Full race footage with high view count showing complete race experience including challenging climbs and crashes.

quotes.text: It's pretty hard packed right now which is pretty surprising how wet it's been. Lots of potholes watch out for. Well we are in Michigan.
There was a lot of Sandy spots and even that there was so much more control than ever in my dad's carbon bike.
